actual: The push towards alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, particularly because of the pressures on the dominant auto industry and the negative impact on sectors such as steel and refining, as well as an indirect ripple effect on others such as the regional and local governments. The credit impact on Japan Inc. is weighted to the negative because of the challenges facing the large auto sector, and the direct impact on sectors such as steel and refining. Lower gasoline consumption will also reduce a meaningful source of government tax revenue, which roughly 300 thousand units per year. (MD-Asia Pac Corp & Infra Fin, Cross-Sector: Push for alternative-fuel vehicles presents challenges for Japan Inc.)
expected: The push towards alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, including Japanese auto manufacturers and associated industries, which will make sizable upfront investments in alternative-fuel vehicle technologies while bearing risks around the scale and speed of this vehicle take-up. The risks of miscalculating this transition are substantial.

actual: The push towards alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, particularly because of the pressures on the dominant auto industry and the negative impact on sectors such as steel and refining, as well as an indirect ripple effect on others such as the regional and local governments. The risks of miscalculating this transition are substantial, and the credit impact on Japan Inc. is weighted to the negative. This information is provided in the excerpt from "Cross-Sector: Push for alternative-fuel vehicles presents challenges for Japan Inc." from Moody's Investors Service Corporates.
expected: The push towards alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, including Japanese auto manufacturers and associated industries, which will make sizable upfront investments in alternative-fuel vehicle technologies while bearing risks around the scale and speed of this vehicle take-up. The risks of miscalculating this transition are substantial.

actual: "Ramping up of alternative-fuel vehicles may squeeze automakers' already thin margins. R&D costs and capital investment will increase, but the return is uncertain. In addition, the entry of new carmakers increases competition, while emerging technologies take automakers beyond their core competencies and toward new business models." (filename: MOODY'S INVESTORS SERVICE CORPORATES)
expected: Automakers may face challenges such as increased R&D costs and capital investment, uncertain returns, competition from new carmakers, and the need to develop new business models.

actual: According to the excerpt, the push towards alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, including the large auto sector, steel, and refining. Automakers will make sizable upfront investments in alternative-fuel vehicle technologies while bearing risks around the scale and speed of this vehicle take-up. Lower gasoline consumption will also reduce a meaningful source of government tax revenue, which adoption of a competing technology that would disrupt the automakers’ franchises. These companies must also customize their alternative-fuel car product lines to meet various emissions standards around the world. Increased spending would require offsetting steps such as further cost cuts or increased production efficiency, both of which would be challenging. The risks of miscalculating this transition are substantial.
expected: Automakers may face challenges such as increased R&D costs and capital investment, uncertain returns, competition from new carmakers, and the need to develop new business models.

actual: Automakers and their suppliers face risks over the scale and speed at which such vehicles may be taken up. Both a slower and faster than expected take-up rate would have negative implications for these companies, depending on their own strategy. Ramping up of alternative-fuel vehicles may squeeze automakers' already thin margins. R&D costs and capital investment will increase, but the return is uncertain. In addition, the entry of new carmakers increases competition, while emerging technologies take automakers beyond their core competencies and toward new business models. Increased adoption rates of alternative-fuel vehicles including BEVs can cause a decline in demand for traditional combustion engine cars and pressure used-car prices for these cars when adoption rates accelerate in the mid-2020s. This could lead to losses on the residual value (RV) of leased cars and cars sold with lease-like contracts – a key factor affecting the margin of an automaker's captive finance business. Higher adoption rates of alternative-fuel vehicles including BEVs can cause a decline in demand for traditional combustion engine cars and pressure used-car prices for these cars when adoption rates accelerate in the mid-2020s. This could lead to losses on the residual value (RV) of leased cars and cars sold with lease-like contracts – a key factor affecting the margin of an automaker's captive finance business. (Source: alternative-fuel vehicles.3)
expected: Automakers may face challenges such as increased R&D costs and capital investment, uncertain returns, competition from new carmakers, and the need to develop new business models.

actual: The given context does not provide information on the percentage of total unit sales in Japan that are expected to be accounted for by alternative-fuel vehicles by 2030.
expected: About 60% of total unit sales in Japan are expected to be accounted for by alternative-fuel vehicles by 2030.
About 60% of total unit sales in Japan are expected to be accounted for by alternative-fuel vehicles by 2030.

actual: According to the financial report, it is estimated that all alternative-fuel vehicles will account for about 60% of total unit sales in Japan by 2030. However, BEVs are expected to represent roughly 10% of the total unit sales. (Filename: "Penetration rates of BEVs and other alternative-fuel vehicles vary by region.")
expected: About 60% of total unit sales in Japan are expected to be accounted for by alternative-fuel vehicles by 2030.

actual: According to the excerpt from Moody's Investors Service Corporates, the negative impact of the dominant auto industry is on sectors such as steel and refining, as well as an indirect ripple effect on others such as the regional and local governments. The push toward alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, and the credit impact on Japan Inc. is weighted to the negative because of the challenges facing the large auto sector. Lower gasoline consumption will also reduce a meaningful source of government tax revenue, which funds road construction and public works programs.
expected: The dominant auto industry has a negative impact on sectors such as steel and refining, as well as an indirect ripple effect on others such as the regional and local governments.

actual: The shift towards alternative-fuel vehicles poses a credit challenge for multiple sectors in Japan, including the large auto sector, steel, and refining. The credit impact on Japan Inc. is weighted to the negative because of the challenges facing the large auto sector, and the direct impact on sectors such as steel and refining. Steel-makers face potential reduction in demand and more competition. The decline in demand for traditional combustion engine cars and pressure used-car prices for these cars when adoption rates accelerate in the mid-2020s could lead to losses on the residual value (RV) of leased cars and cars sold with lease-like contracts – a key factor affecting the margin of an automaker's captive finance business. Therefore, the negative impact of the dominant auto industry on other sectors includes reduced demand, increased competition, and potential losses. (MD-Asia Pac Corp & Infra Fin, Cross-Sector: Push for alternative-fuel vehicles presents challenges for Japan Inc.)
expected: The dominant auto industry has a negative impact on sectors such as steel and refining, as well as an indirect ripple effect on others such as the regional and local governments.

Lower gasoline consumption will also reduce a meaningful source of government tax revenue. Therefore, the negative impact of the dominant auto industry is on sectors such as steel and refining, as well as an indirect ripple effect on others such as the regional and local governments.
